didoss@... wrote:
> My problem is usually along the lines of: I make changes to classA, 
> which is used in classB, which is used in classC, which is tested by 
> testC.  So, I have modified testA, which directly tests classA, but 
> don't realize that I have broken something in testC.  My solution is 
> that we run nightlybuilds, and I check the errors/failures the next 
> morning to see if my code changes could have caused any of them.
> 
> It would be nice to be a little more proactive, though,...being able to 
> (easily) find all the tests that are ultimately affected by my code 
> change (iterating through the workspace references until I terminate at 
> all classes that start with "Test", or that are in my test branch).  I 
> know that I can do this manually through Eclipse, but it is not fun - 
> and therefore doesn't get done.

Why can't you just run all the tests?

Why are there so many dependencies on class A? I would break some 
dependencies by inserting interfaces, that way, if you just make sure 
class A continues to respect the contracts of its various interfaces, 
then the impact is contained. That's the point of interfaces (and the 
Liskov Substitution Principle, and indeed, OOP).
